Pit_Observation.activities: Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Läsluttning med HS ca 10 meter. Byig vind med lätt snödrev över 1000 möh. Mr1_25 i liknande sluttning strax efter profilen grävdes. I lagret ner 19-32 cm fanns något svagare som var svårt att se i pågående snödrev. När flaket sprack upp vid handtester kollapsade det i det tunna lagret.

Snjógryfja var tekin í meiri hæð en oftast áður á Oddsskarði. Léttur vindur af norðaustri og alskýjað. Engin ofankoma. Frost um 7 stig. 17 gráðu halli og gryfja vísaði í SE. Sá litli snjór sem kom um helgina virðist hafa sest í gil og dældir. Óverulegt magn, varla mælanlegt samt.
Dýpt gryfju voru 2 metrar niður á fast. Efstu 38cm er mjög þéttur (K) en sjáanleg skil í pakkanum. Neðan vð 38cm var rakari snjór en og hitastigið í 0 gráðum. Mokaði ekki neðar en 50cm og miðað við stikuna þá virtist allt vera eins að þéttleika fyrir neðan.
Hef litlar áhyggjur af þessum snjó.
Paikoin vähäistä tuiskulumenkertymää yksittäisissä paikoissa. Lumenpinta läikykkäästi jäässä. Maa kivirakkaa.
Location was a small north-facing portion of a generally northeast-facing hillside. Facet layer was still dry to moist. On NE parts of slope, the slab was very similar but the weak layer was wet.
Meltwater moved through the upper slab and formed ice lense above Feb weak layer. Weak layer has remained dry to moist.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
Stor Whumf, över 20m i diameter, i området i anslutning till profilen, så resultaten är inte att lita på. Initierade whumf ned 60cm men det svaga lagret låg ned 160cm på vissa plaster inom sprickområdet.
Eventuellt ECTP13 dwn 54 on DH/FC. Garanterat ECTPH.
Dug on a shallower portion of the slope

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope; Snowmobile tracks on slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Typical springtime conditions Everything frozen solid and very stable during the time of the test, as the slope has a NE aspect, while the test was performed just before sunset and this slope had been in the shade for a long time. The surface melt-freeze crust detaches from the snow below it in one whole block by the end of the compression test, but no sliding is observed, and it is also quite thin - 15-20 cm max. If in direct sunlight likely this result would be different. With the warm temps and southerly winds predicted until next weekend, slopes that are in direct sunlight will likely be unstable and wet snow avalanches will occur. Northern slopes like this one will likely be the safest option, especially at times when they are frozen. From the snowpit results it does not seem like this northern slope has received enough sunlight and warmth yet to cause any serious transformation in the layers deeper within the snowpack - the remain as expected given the weather the past month. This may change with the addition warmth this week. The snow is very deep at this location - at least 375cm. The entire snowpack is very hard and extremely difficult to shovel, and well bonded when frozen. After the initial 135cm that were dug out, I was still not able to reach the ground surface after inserting the 240cm probe from there. The layers below the snowpit again seemed extremely hard and well bonded - inserting the probe was difficult and required force the entire time. No avalanche activity observed in the region.
Fully iso-thermic snowpack. It would appear that Spring has arrived on the North Shore.

Below treeline north facing sheltered area. 1F to P hard slab rests above 2mm rounding near surface facets. Stubborn to stability tests but this structure should be avoided on steep continuous slopes. ECTP 30+with Prying at 118 supports this stubborn stability.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown; Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Ski tracks on slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Crown profile. Fatality on March 17. Likely repeater avalanche from Jan 7th cycle. Total HS adjacent (skier's R side) to avalanche avg. 90cm. Crusts observed in other locations nearby but did not show up in this profile.

The Venue of FWQ Bansko 2022. Previuos days warmer, foggy, with slight snowfall at the end of the warming. As a result there is crust below the top 5 cm of powder; Generally quite settled and solid snowpack;

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Crown profile. Snowmobile tracks below path and on adjacent slopes. Guessing remote trigger. SS-AM-R1-D1-O. Unknown date on slide, maybe within 48hrs. Bed surface at 89cm on top of crust. Tests now failing on facets below crust.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche; Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes; Ski tracks on slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This crown profile was performed on the skiers right flank of the avalanche about 10m downslope from the crown and across from the second profile. No wind loading was evident at this pit. Evidence of old crown from January 7 cycle was evident adjacent to crownline. This avalanche was triggered approximately 125m lower on the slope.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent avalanche activity on different slopes; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Objective: Storm snow reactivity, identify 220310 & 220217 MFcr's. Location in open glade at TL. HS=465 cm. WM observed.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug on gentle planar slope at bottom of alpine bowl in a reasonably sheltered area at treeline. Objectives= Test stability of recent storm snow over Mid March SH layer + test Mid Feb and Jan PWLs. 3 Compression tests done as results in lower snowpack were inconsistent. High confidence in results on Sh at 37 cm and FCxr at 68cm. Low confidence in results 90-110cm, would consider DTT to verify these results.
Located on the West flank of Beehive basin, tucked amongst some trees. This site generally receives less sun exposure than most nearby slopes.

Pit_Observation.activities: We snowmobiled slope;

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Lagið 83-85 cm var mjög hagl blandað og skafsnjó sem var talsvert mikil tenging á milli snjókornanna leit út fyrir að vera varhugavert en kom svo í ljós við testin að þetta var mjög vel tengt. Efstu 10 cm þjöppuðust í ECTX testinu en kom þegar ég togaði bara í það lag en við miðlungs álag og rann ekki auðveldlega samt sem áður tel ég það vera varhugaverðasta lagið í prófunum. Heilt yfir búið að skafa úr flestum brekkum og harðfenni þar eftir rigninguna á mánudaginn, talsverð söfnun í norðurvísandi hlíðar í þessari S átt sem er að ganga yfir. vegna veðurs gat ég ekki skoðað kornastærðir.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Brant klippbunden terräng nära passet. Nära stegjärnsföre. På väg upp och ner 0-1 cm i skipen, P-K-hårt. Små fickor mellan sastrugorna med 1F drevnsö, kall. Endast tecken på uppvärmning idag och tidigare dagar över 40 grader trots grytaktik formation. Inget ECT - ovärt.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: 80-85 FC propagerar vid några sparkar i sidan på kolumnen -> mycket stor belastning. I samma sluttning en D2 5-6 dygn gammal, troligen gått på lagret 26-28 cm (PP/DF), möjligen SH.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes; Recent avalanche activity on different slopes; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
Set out looking for preserved SH, found preserved PPsd layers instead.
Down 41cm PPsd layer gave CTM 14,17 (RP) (2/2), and ECTN 25 results. Down 44cm PPsd layer gave CTM 17 (SP) results (1/2).
Monthly snowpit at Milepost 12.
Additionally found vertical percolation columns

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area;
Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Stable snowpack conditions are observed. The new snow from the past two weeks, about 60cm, is well bonded to the hard layer below it at this location and at most locations on the mountain at the moment. The test, after a lot of compression (fluffy snow), causes a breakup in the snow above the hard layer below it, at around 50cm deep, at around CT27, with the remaining snow breaking up more by the end of the test. In most places it is fairly fluffy, without a windblown, surface slab. The layers below the fresh surface snow from the past two weeks are very well bonded and similar in hardness. Things may change this week with the warmup - the surface layer may become denser and heavier, and it could potentially start to slide more easily on the hard layer below it. No avalanche activity is noticed in the region.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Clear in the morning with increasing clouds and southerly winds ahead of a storm system tracking to the north. Pit dug in a Ski Area;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: I dug a pit on a 13 degree NE Slope at 7784 feet. The layer of concern I was looking to observe was the near surface facets around 10 centimeters down between two crusts. The layer was still there and had become more reactive than the previous day though still not a likely danger.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; We skied slope;

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Liten kulle som korsladdat drevsnö på sydsida fastän det blåst storm SW-W under natten. Snabb profil för att undersöka den mjuka snön under drevsnöflaket. Fick ECTPV först, men darrade med sågen. ECTP2 när jag var superförsiktig med sågen.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Snöytan täkt av små snöklumpar. Dessa fanns på hela ytan och på flera ställen på fjället. ECTPV var troligtvis påverkad av sågen/staven vid friläggning och brottet gick mellan 19 och 35 cm.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Very cold night (-20C); Dry powder snow from previous days on top of older powder snow from the 2-week storm cycle; Small dry loose avalanches from very steep locations; Older bigger dry loose avalanches on the North face (from the top), but now under the fresh snow; The top part of the slope with less snow due to the NE winds and steepness;
